channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Korean Coast Guard Video of Ferry Rescue
item.description: Video released by the South Korean Coast Guard showed survivors being plucked from a sinking ferry by helicopter and boat as the ship slowly capsized.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Ukraine’s Push East Falters as Militants Seize Army Vehicles
item.description: Ukrainian news media reported that pro-Russian militias had commandeered six armored personnel carriers from the Ukrainian Army and driven them to the central square in Slovyansk.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian militants guarded armored personnel carriers and displayed a Russian flag along side their militia flag on Wednesday in the central square of Slovyansk.

item.title: Taliban Say They Killed 7 Afghan Policemen
item.description: The authorities in Wardak Province said they had reports that a dozen officers had been kidnapped by insurgents while traveling to Kabul in order to collect their salaries.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: A List of Demands Greets Twitter Delegation in Turkey
item.description: Amid tensions over leaks on Twitter about an ongoing graft inquiry, company representatives attempted to smooth things over with the Turkish government.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU and TIM ARANGO

item.title: Citing Russian Moves, NATO Plans New Deployments
item.description: Declaring “NATO will protect every ally,” Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the secretary general, said the alliance would send more planes, ships and personnel to the region around Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said on Wednesday that NATO would increase patrols along its eastern border in response to Russian interference in Ukraine.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 16
item.description: A passenger train derailed in Morigaon district of Assam injuring at least 45 people, according to local media reports.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: BG Express, a passenger train traveling between Kamakhya and Dimapur, derailed near Ajuri railway station in Morigaon district of Assam. Local media reports said at least 45 people were injured in the accident.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: National Security Commission Meets for the First Time
item.description: Comments by President Xi Jinping suggested that the new commission would have the power to reach into nearly every aspect of domestic and foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: Pushing the 2-State Path in Gaza
item.description: Ezzeldin Masri runs the Gaza branch of OneVoice, promoting a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict despite continuous setbacks.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Female Candidate Navigates Hurdle-Filled Campaign Trail in India
item.description: Shefali Misra of the Aam Aadmi Party is seeking a parliamentary seat amid elections awash in illegal cash, serious violence and dirty tricks.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: At War Blog: Days of Tea and Honey: Memories of a Quiet Iraq
item.description: A look back at a time when Marines thought Iraq had finally achieved a tentative peace and were able to take time to simply share a meal with elders.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By BLAKE J. RICE
item.media:description: A summer sand storm in the Iraqi province of Nineveh.

item.title: India Ink: A Story of Displacement in Gujarat Comes to Mumbai
item.description: Mallika Sarabhai, an Indian classical dancer, has organized a festival to pay tribute to river residents forced to leave their homes for the sake of development in Ahmedabad, in the western state of Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: By ZAHIR JANMOHAMED
item.media:description: Performers during the Vikram Sarabhai International Arts Festival in Ahmedabad, India, before its reprise in Mumbai.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Author Sanjaya Baru
item.description: Sanjaya Baru, author of “The Accidental Prime Minister,” spoke with India Ink about dynastic politics and the failures and successes of Manmohan Singh.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: India Ink: Candidates Exploit Loopholes to Skirt Spending Limits
item.description: The parliamentary elections in Bangalore show the gap between candidates’ actual expenses and spending statements. For example, one way around the campaign limit is to spend money before filing nomination papers.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI
item.media:description: Publicity material of Narendra Modi, prime ministerial candidate of Bharatiya Janata Party, on sale in Bangalore, Karnataka, on Sunday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Official Praises Eviction Workers as ‘Most Lovable’
item.description: The official, a district Communist Party secretary in the Henan Province city of Xinyang, has been criticized nationally after praising demolition crews carrying out one of the most controversial policies in China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Working at a demolition site in preparation for new development in Hefei, in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui.

item.title: Hundreds Missing After South Korean Ferry Sinks
item.description: It is unclear what caused the sinking of the Sewol, which was traveling to the resort island of Jeju. More than 280 passengers on board are still unaccounted for.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Reading Valentine’s Card, Pistorius Leaves the Stand
item.description: Oscar Pistorius’s defense lawyer began to rebuild his case after days of grueling interrogation by the prosecutor, who has accused the athlete of lying and changing his testimony.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius in Pretoria on Tuesday, after five days of aggressive questioning by prosecutors.

item.title: Lens Blog: Photos That Cross Borders and Challenge Perceptions
item.description: Janet Jarman has followed Marisol from her childhood in Mexico to life as a young mother in the United States, making images that are educating teachers and doctors about the complexities of immigrant life.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Marisol, in flowered shirt, enjoying an outing with her mother, Andrés and all of her sisters and their families. They attended a public dance featuring Mexican bands. Because of financial constraints, Marisol and Andrés rarely go out. Texas. 2011.

item.title: Pistorius Trial to Adjourn After Hearings Until May 5
item.description: The delay in the murder trial of the disabled track star Oscar Pistorius was requested by the prosecution.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Growth Rose 7.4% in First Quarter, China Reports
item.description: The year-on-year growth was the slowest since the third quarter of 2012.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 16
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Cloth in Congress party colors surrounding a worker in Ahmedabad, in the western Indian state of Gujarat, on Tuesday.

item.title: Rescuers Rush to South Korean Ferry Accident
item.description: A ferry carrying hundreds of high school students to a resort island listed and began sinking off the southwestern tip of South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The vessel was carrying 477 passengers and crew, including 325 high school students.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Jordan’s Envoy Is Held Hostage
item.description: Jordan’s ambassador to Libya, Fawaz al-Itan, was kidnapped on Tuesday by gunmen who demanded that an Islamist militant be released from a Jordanian jail in exchange for the diplomat’s freedom.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Norway Returns a Rare Silent Film to China
item.description: A print of “The Cave of the Silken Web,” released in 1927, is believed to be the only existing copy of the film, which was directed by Dan Duyu and is based on an episode from the Chinese classic novel “Journey to the West.”
item.category: The Cave of the Silken Web (Movie)
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:credit: National Library of Norway, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A scene from the 1927 Chinese film "The Cave of the Silken Web."

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: Opposition Talks Resume
item.description: Venezuela’s opposition resumed negotiations with the government on Tuesday, despite rising doubts that the talks will produce a political opening.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: 5 Students Killed in Alberta
item.description: A guest at an end-of-semester party in Calgary, Alberta, stabbed and killed five other university students early Tuesday morning, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
